description: From Middle English apreisen, from Old French aprisier (“apraise, set a price on”) (compare modern French apprécier), from Late Latin appretiare, from ad- + Latin pretium (“price, value”) (English precious), from which also appreciate, a doublet.

verbs.description: appraise (third-person singular simple present appraises, present participle appraising, simple past and past participle appraised)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To determine the value or worth of (something), particularly as a person appointed for this purpose.
(transitive) To judge the performance of someone, especially a worker.
examples: At the end of the contract, you will be appraised by your line manager.

description: Form of apprise in use since 1706 but considered incorrect by some.

verbs.description: appraise (third-person singular simple present appraises, present participle appraising, simple past and past participle appraised)
